What is the most frequent site of ectopic gastric mucosa?

questions.question: A 57-year-old man came with complaints of difficulty in swallowing and a persistent feeling ofsomething stuck in his throat. He also reports bad breath and regurgitation of food particles.Barium swallow revealed the following. This condition occurs due to a defect in which of thefollowing?977
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario and barium swallow image are diagnostic of Zenker's diverticulum. Itoccurs due to a defect in the Killian's triangle (Killian's dehiscence).Killian's triangle is an anatomical triangular area bordered superiorly by the firm oblique fibers ofthe thyropharyngeus muscle and inferiorly by the horizontal fibers of the cricopharyngeus muscle.It is located immediately above the upper esophageal sphincter.Although the Killian-Jamieson diverticulum is an anterolateral defect, it is rarely symptomatic.

questions.question: All of the following may be seen in patients with Plummer-Vinson syndrome except:
questions.explanation: Paterson-Brown-Kelly or Plummer-Vinson syndrome is associated with non-progressivedysphagia, especially with incompletely chewed food.This syndrome is common in women aged >40 years. The other components of this syndromeare:•• Post-cricoid webs in the upper esophagus• Iron-deficiency anemia• Glossitis• CheilosisEsophageal webs are idiopathic, semi-circumferential lesions composed of fibrovascularconnective tissue and overlying epithelium. They are usually limited to the proximalesophagus and may cause obstruction. questions.question: A 52-year-old woman is being evaluated for dysphagia and chest pain. She traveled to Brazilon a business trip 5 months ago. Barium swallow reveals the following finding. Which of thefollowing could have caused this condition?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario and barium swallow showing the bird-beak appearance are suggestiveof achalasia cardia. With respect to this patient's travel history, Chagas' disease due to infectionwith Trypanosoma cruzi must be suspected.The infection destroys the myenteric plexus which results in failure of peristalsis and esophagealdilatation. Duodenal, colonic, and ureteric myenteric plexuses can also be affected by Chagas'disease.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is true about the pathology of achalasia cardia?

options.C: Decreased release of NO and VIP in the distal part of esophagus
options.D: Decreased tone of the lower esophageal sphincter

questions.explanation: Achalasia cardia is characterized by decreased release of NO(nitric oxide) and VIP(vasoactiveintestinal polypeptide) in the distal part of esophagus.Normally, NO and VIP are secreted by the inhibitory neurons of the Auerbach's plexus in thedistal esophagus. This leads to relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES). In achalasiacardia, these inhibitory neurons degenerate leading to decreased release of NO and VIP. Thiscauses increased LES tone.The triad of achalasia cardia is as follows:• Incomplete relaxation of LES• Increased tone of LES• Absent peristalsis (aperistalisis)

questions.question: A 47-year-old woman comes to you with progressive heartburn and difficulty in swallowing.She also describes episodes of painful blanching and bluish discoloration of her fingers andtoes on exposure to cold. The following findings are noted on examination. Antibodies towhich of the following are most likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.explanation: The symptoms of the patient in the above case scenario and the image showing calcinosis are thecharacteristic findings of the CREST syndrome or limited scleroderma. Patients with thiscondition characteristically have antibodies directed against centromeric proteins(anti-centromere antibodies).CREST syndrome is characterized by the following:• Calcinosis•Raynaud phenomenon• Esophageal dysmotility• Sclerodactyly• TelangiectasiaIn the esophagus, progressive atrophy and fibrous replacement of the muscularis propria leads tohypomotility and dysphagia. The lower 2/3 of the esophagus develops arubber-hose-like inflexibility. The associated dysfunction of the lower esophageal sphincter givesrise to gastroesophageal reflux, Barrett metaplasia, and stricture.

questions.question: A 50-year-old man presented with blood in his vomitus. He gives a history of binge drinkingfollowed by multiple episodes of vomiting the prior night. He is hemodynamically stable.981Which of the following is incorrect about this condition?

options.A: It is due to longitudinal mucosal tears
options.B: The gastroesophageal musculature fails to relax
options.C: The tears cross the gastroesophageal junction

questions.explanation: This clinical scenario is suggestive of a Mallory-Weiss tear. They require only conservativemanagement and healing tends to be rapid and complete.They are longitudinal mucosal tears that may cross the gastroesophageal junction (GEJ).Forceful retching or vomiting along with failure of reflex relaxation of the gastroesophagealmusculature results in tears involving the mucosa and submucosa. It usually occurs secondary toconditions like acute alcohol intoxication or hyperemesis gravidarum.Boerhaave syndrome is a much more serious disorder characterized by transmural rupture of thedistal esophagus. This results in acute mediastinitis with severe chest pain, tachypnea, and shock.Such patients generally require urgent surgical intervention.991

questions.question: What is the most frequent cause of esophagitis?
questions.explanation: The most frequent cause of esophagitis is reflux of gastric acid into the lower esophagus.The most common cause of gastroesophageal reflux is transient lower esophageal sphincterrelaxation. Reflux esophagitis leads to chronic gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). This cancause Barrett's esophagus and eventually can cause adenocarcinoma.

questions.question: Which organism can cause esophageal infections in healthy individuals?
questions.explanation: Esophagitis in healthy individuals can be caused by the Herpes simplex virus. However, it isrelatively uncommon.In immunosuppressed individuals, infections can be caused by:• Herpes simplex virusCytomegalovirus• Candida

questions.question: Which of the following statements is false?

options.A: The most common site of extranodal lymphoma in GIT is the esophagus
options.B: The most common benign tumour of esophagus is leimyoma
